title: Gerald Lathbury
text:
<a href="General%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">General</a> Sir Gerald William Lathbury, (14 July 1906 – 16 May 1978) was a senior <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> <a href="Officer%20%28armed%20forces%29">officer</a> who fought during the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a>, serving with distinction with the British Army's <a href="airborne%20forces">airborne forces</a>, commanding the <a href="1st%20Parachute%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">1st Parachute Brigade</a> in <a href="Allied%20invasion%20of%20Sicily">Sicily</a>, <a href="Allied%20invasion%20of%20Italy">Italy</a> and <a href="Operation%20Market%20Garden">Holland</a>. He later became <a href="Governor%20of%20Gibraltar">Governor of Gibraltar</a> from 1965 to 1969.
Early life and military career.
Gerald Lathbury was born in <a href="Murree">Murree</a>, <a href="British%20Raj">British India</a> on 14 July 1906 into a military family, his father being Colonel (Henry) Oscar Lathbury. Returning to England, he was educated at <a href="Wellington%20College%2C%20Berkshire">Wellington College, Berkshire</a> and the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>. <a href="Passing%20out%20%28military%29">Passing out</a> from Sandhurst, Lathbury was <a href="Officer%20%28armed%20forces%29">commissioned</a> as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> into the <a href="Oxfordshire%20and%20Buckinghamshire%20Light%20Infantry">Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry</a> on 4 February 1926. He was seconded to the <a href="Royal%20West%20African%20Frontier%20Force">Royal West African Frontier Force</a> and <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Regiment">Gold Coast Regiment</a> between 1928 and 1932 and, returning to England, attended the <a href="Staff%20College%2C%20Camberley">Staff College, Camberley</a> between 1937 and 1938. Promoted to lieutenant on 4 February 1929, he was a captain on 21 March 1938. In January 1939 he became <a href="brigade%20major">brigade major</a> with the <a href="8th%20Infantry%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">8th Infantry Brigade</a>, which formed part of the <a href="3rd%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">3rd Infantry Division</a>, whose <a href="General%20Officer%20Commanding">General Officer Commanding</a> (GOC) was <a href="Major-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Major General</a> <a href="Denis%20Bernard%20%28British%20Army%20officer%29">Denis Bernard</a> until he was succeeded in August by Major General <a href="Bernard%20Montgomery">Bernard Montgomery</a>, shortly before the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a> began the following month.
Second World War.
Soon after the war began the 3rd Division was sent to <a href="France">France</a> where it became one of four divisions forming the initial <a href="British%20Expeditionary%20Force%20%28World%20War%20II%29">British Expeditionary Force</a> (BEF), although there was no immediate action. On 29 February 1940, Lathbury, promoted to the <a href="Acting%20%28rank%29">acting rank</a> of <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a>, was posted to the <a href="48th%20%28South%20Midland%29%20Division">48th (South Midland) Infantry Division</a> as a <a href="Staff%20%28military%29">General Staff Officer Grade 2</a> (GSO2). The division, commanded by Major General <a href="Andrew%20Thorne">Andrew Thorne</a>, was a first line <a href="Army%20Reserve%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Territorial Army</a> formation which had only recently arrived in France. The <a href="German%20Army%20%28Wehrmacht%29">German Army</a> launched their <a href="Battle%20of%20France">invasion of France</a> just over two months later, and the 48th Division, along with most of the rest of the BEF, was forced to <a href="Battle%20of%20Dunkirk">retreat to Dunkirk</a>, from where most of it was <a href="Dunkirk%20evacuation">evacuated at Dunkirk</a>. For his services in France and Belgium Lathbury was made a <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Member of the Order of the British Empire</a>. For the rest of the year the division was in <a href="South%20West%20England">South West England</a> on <a href="Operation%20Sea%20Lion">anti-invasion duties</a>.
In September 1941, however, Lathbury's career took a sharp upwards turn as, interested in the British Army's newly created <a href="airborne%20forces">airborne forces</a>, he was made <a href="Commanding%20Officer">Commanding Officer</a> (CO) of the <a href="3rd%20Battalion%2C%20Parachute%20Regiment">3rd Parachute Battalion</a>. The battalion was one of three − the others being <a href="Ernest%20Down">Ernest Down</a>'s <a href="1st%20Battalion%2C%20Parachute%20Regiment">1st</a> and <a href="Edwin%20Flavell%20%28British%20Army%20officer%29">Edwin Flavell</a>'s <a href="2nd%20Battalion%2C%20Parachute%20Regiment">2nd Parachute Battalion</a>s − which formed part of <a href="Brigadier%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Brigadier</a> <a href="Richard%20Gale%20%28British%20Army%20officer%29">Richard Gale</a>'s <a href="1st%20Parachute%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">1st Parachute Brigade</a>, which in December became part of the <a href="1st%20Airborne%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">1st Airborne Division</a>, whose GOC was Major General <a href="Frederick%20Browning">Frederick Browning</a>. Lathbury trained his battalion very hard over the next few months until, in May 1942, he was posted as a GSO1 to the Air Directorate at the <a href="War%20Office">War Office</a>.
In December, however, he returned to the command of troops when he was promoted to the acting rank of brigadier and was given command of the <a href="3rd%20Parachute%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">3rd Parachute Brigade</a>, taking over from Brigadier <a href="Alexander%20Stanier">Alexander Stanier</a>. The brigade, part of the 1st Airborne Division, still under Browning, was a recent creation, comprising the <a href="7th%20%28Light%20Infantry%29%20Parachute%20Battalion">7th</a>, <a href="8th%20%28Midlands%29%20Parachute%20Battalion">8th</a> and <a href="9th%20%28Eastern%20and%20Home%20Counties%29%20Parachute%20Battalion">9th Parachute Battalion</a>s, all of which had formerly been infantry battalions converted into parachute battalions, along with supporting units. Created to replace the 1st Parachute Brigade after it was detached to fight in North Africa (see <a href="British%20airborne%20operations%20in%20North%20Africa">British airborne operations in North Africa</a>), Lathbury, as he had done with the 3rd Para Battalion the previous year, put the 3rd Para Brigade through a series of gruelling training <a href="Military%20exercise">exercises</a>, before, in mid-April 1943, he was selected to command the 1st Para Brigade in North Africa, in succession to Brigadier Edwin Flavell, handing over the 3rd Para Brigade to Brigadier <a href="James%20Hill%20%28British%20Army%20officer%29">James Hill</a>.
The brigade, which as previously mentioned had been detached from its parent 1st Airborne Division, had just been engaged in hard fighting in the <a href="Tunisian%20Campaign">Tunisian Campaign</a>, and had sustained heavy losses. Lathbury took part in the <a href="Allied%20invasion%20of%20Sicily">landings in Sicily</a> (Operation Husky), his brigade being tasked with the <a href="Operation%20Fustian">capture of the Primosole Bridge</a>, where he was wounded in the back and both thighs, although he remained in command until reinforcement arrived. He was awarded the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> (DSO) for this action. The citation reads:
Lathbury was still in command of the 1st Parachute Brigade during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Arnhem">Battle of Arnhem</a>, part of <a href="Operation%20Market%20Garden">Operation Market Garden</a> in the Netherlands. On 18 September 1944 he was cut off from his command while in the company of Major General <a href="Roy%20Urquhart">Roy Urquhart</a>, the division's GOC, when he was badly wounded in the left leg and his spine was chipped, leaving him temporarily paralysed. Lathbury was left in the care of a local Dutch family and became a <a href="prisoner%20of%20war">prisoner of war</a>. He concealed his rank, pretending to be a <a href="lance%20corporal">lance corporal</a>. He escaped with help of the Dutch resistance by simply walking out of the main doors of the hospital in which he was held. The <a href="Dutch%20resistance">Dutch resistance</a> put him in touch with other hiding British soldiers. Lathbury, along with Lieutenant Colonel <a href="David%20Dobie">David Dobie</a> and Major <a href="Digby%20Tatham-Warter">Digby Tatham-Warter</a>, organised an <a href="Operation%20Pegasus">escape across the Rhine</a>. Lathbury and Digby crossed the Rhine on 22 October with 137 personnel, linking up with US paratroopers of <a href="First%20lieutenant">First Lieutenant</a> <a href="Frederick%20Heyliger">Frederick Heyliger</a>'s <a href="E%20Company%2C%20506th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">Company E</a> of the 2nd Battalion, <a href="506th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">506th Parachute Infantry Regiment</a>, part of the <a href="101st%20Airborne%20Division">U.S 101st Airborne Division</a>. Lathbury was portrayed by <a href="Donald%20Douglas%20%28Scottish%20actor%29">Donald Douglas</a> in the 1977 film "<a href="A%20Bridge%20Too%20Far%20%28film%29">A Bridge Too Far</a>".
On 9 May 1945 Brigadier Lathbury arrived in Copenhagen to oversee the surrender of German forces in Denmark as part of Operation Eclipse.
Postwar.
Lathbury remained with the 1st Para Brigade, which did not see any further action during the war, and in July 1945 returned to his old 3rd Para Brigade as its commander. The brigade formed part of the <a href="6th%20Airborne%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">6th Airborne Division</a>, then under Major General <a href="Eric%20Bols">Eric Bols</a>, and was sent with the rest of the division to <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">Palestine</a> towards the end of the year, at the height of the <a href="Jewish%20insurgency%20in%20Mandatory%20Palestine">Palestine Emergency</a> (see <a href="6th%20Airborne%20Division%20in%20Palestine">6th Airborne Division in Palestine</a>).
Returning to England, he attended the <a href="Royal%20College%20of%20Defence%20Studies">Imperial Defence College</a> as a student in 1948. He was appointed GOC of the <a href="16th%20Airborne%20Division">16th Airborne Division</a> in 1948 and then <a href="Commandant">Commandant</a> of the Staff College, Camberley in 1951. He went on to be <a href="Commander-in-chief">Commander-in-Chief</a> (C-in-C) of <a href="East%20Africa%20Command">East Africa Command</a> in 1955 and, returning to England, Director General of Military Training at the <a href="War%20Office">War Office</a> in 1957. He became General Officer Commanding-in-Chief (GOC-in-C) of <a href="Eastern%20Command%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Eastern Command</a> in 1960 and <a href="Quartermaster-General%20to%20the%20Forces">Quartermaster-General to the Forces</a> the following year. Finally he was appointed <a href="Governor%20of%20Gibraltar">Governor of Gibraltar</a> in 1964; he retired in 1969. He was described as radiating "a serene imperturbability" by <a href="Joshua%20Hassan">Joshua Hassan</a>, who was a <a href="Chief%20Minister%20of%20Gibraltar">Chief Minister of Gibraltar</a>. Lathbury's composure was invaluable at the time as the politics meant there was doubts over the status of Gibraltar, with questions being asked at the United Nations. This made the locals nervous, especially as there was a de facto freeze on take home pay in Gibraltar.
He was also an <a href="Aide-de-camp%20general">Aide-de-camp general</a> to <a href="Elizabeth%20II">the Queen</a> from 1962 to 1965 as well as <a href="Colonel%20Commandant">Colonel Commandant</a> of both the <a href="1st%20Green%20Jackets%20%2843rd%20and%2052nd%29">1st Green Jackets (43rd and 52nd)</a> and the <a href="Parachute%20Regiment%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Parachute Regiment</a> from 1961 to 1965. In 1965 he participated in the third of the series of <a href="Harold%20Hall%20Australian%20Expeditions">Harold Hall Australian ornithological collecting expeditions</a>.
Family.
In 1942 he married Jean Gordon Thin: they had two daughters. In 1972 he married Mairi Zoë Gibbs, widow of Patrick Somerset Gibbs. He died in 1978. There is a <a href="Lathbury%20Barracks">Lathbury Barracks</a> in Gibraltar and <a href="Jamaica">Jamaica</a> at the <a href="Jamaica%20Defence%20Force">Jamaica Defence Force</a> Headquarters at <a href="Up%20Park%20Camp">Up Park Camp</a> in <a href="Kingston%2C%20Jamaica">Kingston</a>.
